summary: The document is a declassified intelligence report from August 1964, detailing information about Comandante Jose Fernandez, a high-ranking Cuban military officer. It covers his roles, physical description, political affiliations, military education in the United States, and his non-Communist stance. The report also highlights his close relationship with Fidel and Raul Castro, his involvement in significant military operations, and training programs in Cuba. Various sources provide conflicting views on Fernandez's political leanings.
key_findings: Comandante Jose Fernandez, nicknamed 'El Gallego', was a key figure in the Cuban military, involved in training and defense strategies.
Despite his high-ranking position, Fernandez was reported to not be a Communist, maintaining a strictly military focus and avoiding political involvement.
Fernandez had a close relationship with Fidel and Raul Castro, contributing to military preparations and Castro's trip to the Soviet Union in 1963.
The document includes detailed physical descriptions of Fernandez and notes his military education in the United States.
Various sources provide conflicting views on Fernandez's political leanings, with some emphasizing his anti-Communist stance and others noting his loyalty to Castro.
